messages.author: Evan Stade
messages.text: this should only have 4 spaces of indent

messages.author: Evan Stade
messages.text: use modulus division and do it in selectSuggestionAtIndex

messages.author: jeremycho
messages.text:
On 2012/12/17 20:04:45, Evan Stade wrote:

Done.

messages.author: jeremycho
messages.text:
On 2012/12/17 20:04:45, Evan Stade wrote:
> use modulus division and do it in selectSuggestionAtIndex

AFICAT, modulus division doesn't make this cleaner since it only handles looping in one direction:
selectedIndex = (selectedIndex + 1) % numSuggestions - 1;
if (selectedIndex < -1)
  selectedIndex = numSuggestions - 1.

Also, I personally prefer having the precondition of selectSuggestionAtIndex be that the index is properly set.

messages.author: Evan Stade
messages.text:
On 2012/12/17 21:01:28, jeremycho wrote:
> On 2012/12/17 20:04:45, Evan Stade wrote:
> > use modulus division and do it in selectSuggestionAtIndex
> 
> AFICAT, modulus division doesn't make this cleaner since it only handles looping
> in one direction:
> selectedIndex = (selectedIndex + 1) % numSuggestions - 1;
> if (selectedIndex < -1)
>   selectedIndex = numSuggestions - 1.

For the increment case,

  (selectedIndex + 1) % numSuggestions - 1;

is sufficient.

For decrement,

  (numSuggestions + selectedIndex - 1) % numSuggestions - 1;

> 
> Also, I personally prefer having the precondition of selectSuggestionAtIndex be
> that the index is properly set.

that's fine, except then you have to check for over/under flow every time you use the function, which apparently is something that's hard to remember to do. Even if you do remember, you have to write code for it every time instead of just once.

messages.author: jeremycho
messages.text:
Actually, neither of those will work.  E.g. for increment, when selectedIndex = 3, numSuggestions = 4, you get -1 instead of 3.

Moved this to updateSelectedSuggestion with the current looping logic - it might still be possible to do with modulo division, but I think it's clearer what's happening this way.

On 2012/12/17 21:09:06, Evan Stade wrote:
> On 2012/12/17 21:01:28, jeremycho wrote:
> > On 2012/12/17 20:04:45, Evan Stade wrote:
> > > use modulus division and do it in selectSuggestionAtIndex
> > 
> > AFICAT, modulus division doesn't make this cleaner since it only handles
> looping
> > in one direction:
> > selectedIndex = (selectedIndex + 1) % numSuggestions - 1;
> > if (selectedIndex < -1)
> >   selectedIndex = numSuggestions - 1.
> 
> For the increment case,
> 
>   (selectedIndex + 1) % numSuggestions - 1;
> 
> is sufficient.
> 
> For decrement,
> 
>   (numSuggestions + selectedIndex - 1) % numSuggestions - 1;
> 
> > 
> > Also, I personally prefer having the precondition of selectSuggestionAtIndex
> be
> > that the index is properly set.
> 
> that's fine, except then you have to check for over/under flow every time you
> use the function, which apparently is something that's hard to remember to do.
> Even if you do remember, you have to write code for it every time instead of
> just once.
